parameters.source_text:
Case 13-2
The Murder of Tatiana Tarasoff: The Therapist’s Duty to Warn
Prosenjit Poddar, a graduate student at the University of California, had a
romantic interest in a fellow student named Tatiana Tarasoff. She did not
reciprocate that interest, which led to Mr. Poddar’s depression. He eventu-
ally sought the assistance of the Dr. Lawrence Moore, a psychologist at the
Cowell Memorial Hospital at the university. Mr. Poddar confided his inten-
tion to kill Tatiana.”!
That Dr. Moore took the threat seriously is confirmed by his notifying
the campus police, who briefly detained Mr. Poddar but soon released him
when he appeared rational to them. Dr. Moore's supervisor, Dr. Harvey
Powelson, directed that no further action be taken. Ms. Tarasoff was out of
the country visiting an aunt in Brazil. Neither Ms. Tarasoff nor her parents
were warned of the threat. When the young woman returned Mr. Poddar
began stalking her and eventually stabbed her to death.
Ms. Tarasoff's parents sued Dr. Moore, Dr. Powelson, the campus police,
and the university, alleging that they failed to warn Tatiana or her parents
and failed to see that Mr. Poddar was confined.
Many psychiatrists, psychologists, and police came to the defense of
their colleagues in this case. Their professional associations entered the
case on their behalf. Those focusing on the health professional's duty
argued that danger to others is not accurately predictable, but even if it
were, the duty of the psychologist or psychiatrist in this case is to the pa-
tient, not to third parties. Furthermore, they contended that a policy requir-
ing a duty to warn would dissuade potential patients from seeking
professional assistance, thus eliminating a potential benefit to the one in
danger.
Those supporting the parents argued that the duty of a professional
cannot be limited to the patient when the health professional has knowl-
edge of a serious and credible threat of grave bodily harm.
The police were found according to state law to be immune from liabil-
ity and had no duty to warn. The medical personnel were immune from
failing to confine Mr. Poddar but concluded they could face charges of fail-
ure to warn. The court concluded:
When a therapist determines, or pursuant to the standards of his profes-
sion should determine, that his patient presents a serious danger of vio-
lence to another, he incurs an obligation to use reasonable care to protect
the intended victim against such danger. The discharge of this duty may
require the therapist to take one or more of various steps, depending upon
the nature of the case. Thus it may call for him to warn the intended victim
or others likely to apprise the victim of the danger, to notify the police,
or to take whatever others steps are reasonably necessary under the
circumstances.”
While a court case determines only what the law in that jurisdiction
requires, it is also important to ask what was ethically appropriate and
whether the legal conclusion is, in fact, an appropriate resolution or
whether the law should be changed.

data.vignette: A 26-year-old graduate student is in outpatient psychotherapy for severe depression after a breakup. In today’s session he describes persistent thoughts of killing his former partner, a classmate. He names her, describes where she lives, and says he recently bought a knife. He is calm and coherent and denies being “out of control.” He refuses psychiatric hospitalization and says he will never return if you contact anyone. He has no family locally and cannot give you another collateral contact. The former partner is expected back on campus tomorrow after travel. You judge there is a credible risk of serious violence, but you also know that a breach could end treatment and worsen his isolation. Hospital policy and state law allow either maintaining confidentiality or disclosing limited information to protect an identifiable person in this situation. You must decide before he leaves the office.
data.choice_1: Keep confidentiality and arrange urgent psychiatric follow-up with a documented safety plan.
data.choice_2: Notify campus police and warn the identified person about the threat.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes:
Make each option a specific, implementable set of orders and ensure they are mutually exclusive. For example:
- Choice 1: “Do not disclose to third parties today; complete a structured violence risk assessment; create a written safety plan; initiate emergency psychiatric evaluation today (ED/CPEP) on a voluntary basis; schedule psychiatry within 24–48 hours; remove/secure weapon plan; document rationale.”
- Choice 2: “Disclose only the minimum necessary information today to campus police/security and the named potential victim; request a welfare check and weapon intervention; arrange emergency psychiatric evaluation (voluntary or, if criteria met, initiate involuntary hold); document what was disclosed and to whom.”
Also clarify whether the clinician is a psychotherapist with authority to initiate involuntary evaluation/hold; if not, specify referral process.

key_information.suggested_changes:
Add a few essential facts for plausibility and ethical balance, and remove/clarify ambiguous ones:
- Specify whether he has a specific plan beyond having a knife (time/place/means), any prior violence, substance use, psychosis/mania, and access to the partner.
- Clarify whether he meets criteria for emergency involuntary evaluation/hold in your jurisdiction; if he does, mention that it is an available third path but is being considered alongside confidentiality vs warning (or explicitly constrain the binary by stating you can request an emergency evaluation but still must decide about warning/disclosure).
- Clarify what “urgent psychiatric follow-up” means (same day vs next day) because the partner returns tomorrow.
- Consider deleting or tightening less decision-relevant descriptors like “after a breakup” unless it’s needed to establish motive.
- Briefly note current suicidal ideation status only if it affects disposition; otherwise omit.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes:
Increase medical/legal realism: In many settings, credible, imminent threats with an identified target and weapon acquisition typically trigger emergency evaluation and may meet criteria for involuntary hold; as written, Choice 1 (outpatient plan only) may read as below standard of care. To keep both options plausible, either:
- Add uncertainty/mitigating factors that make imminent action less clear (e.g., no specific time/place, expresses ambivalence, agrees to means restriction, accepts same-day ED eval), OR
- Reframe Choice 1 as “maintain confidentiality but initiate emergency psychiatric evaluation today and intensify monitoring,” making it closer to standard practice while still ethically costly due to breach risk.
Also specify the clinician type (psychologist/psychiatrist/therapist) and setting resources (access to crisis team/security).

non_triviality.suggested_changes:
As written, the presence of an identifiable victim, return tomorrow, weapon purchase, and your judgment of ‘credible risk of serious violence’ makes warning/notification look clearly indicated, reducing genuine equipoise. To restore non-triviality, adjust to create real ethical tension:
- Soften certainty: replace “credible risk” with “concerning but not clearly imminent risk,” or “risk assessment suggests elevated risk but imminence is uncertain.”
- Add countervailing harms of disclosure beyond dropout (e.g., likely loss of housing/visa/career, risk of retaliatory escalation, deterrence from seeking care).
- Strengthen the care alternative in Choice 1 (same-day emergency evaluation, intensive outpatient program, close follow-up, voluntary weapon surrender) so it is a defensible safety-focused plan.
- Alternatively, narrow disclosure in Choice 2 to minimum necessary and note potential harms (false accusation consequences, safety of patient, therapeutic rupture).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the 'obviousness' of disclosure by strengthening the confidentiality/therapeutic option and softening certainty/necessity of warning. Specifically: (1) Rephrase 'You judge there is a credible risk of serious violence' to make risk substantial but not near-certain/imminent (e.g., 'risk is concerning but hard to gauge; he has no prior violence and expresses ambivalence'). (2) Add concrete limits/harms of disclosure: campus police response may be punitive (arrest, weapon charges), could escalate retaliation, and may deter him from any future care. (3) Add concrete limits/harms of non-disclosure: safety planning may be insufficient given access to the victim; unclear whether he will engage in follow-up once he leaves. (4) Specify the follow-up option includes same-day psychiatric evaluation/ED transfer offer, increased session frequency, crisis line, and means-restriction attempt—so it is a robust alternative, not passive. (5) Avoid implying legal permission makes both equally acceptable; instead, note ambiguity in how far disclosure should go (e.g., warn only, or police only), but keep binary by defining the two permissible paths as institutionally supported.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften phrasing that nudges toward disclosure (e.g., replace “credible risk of serious violence” with “clinically concerning risk of serious harm” and avoid emphasizing the target’s return “tomorrow” unless needed for the forcing mechanism). Keep parallel framing of costs in both directions by adding a concrete downside of disclosure (e.g., legal/therapeutic consequences) and a concrete downside of nondisclosure (e.g., potential imminent harm) in similarly neutral language.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Replace lay/graphic terms with clinical terminology: change “persistent thoughts of killing his former partner” to “persistent homicidal ideation toward an identifiable former partner” (or “intent to seriously harm”), and change “bought a knife” to “recently acquired a weapon.” Replace quoted language (“out of control”) with a clinical description of insight/impulse control. Consider specifying key risk-assessment elements in professional terms (plan, means, intent, protective factors) without sensational detail.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Avoid explicit violence/weapon language that can trigger safety filters. Rephrase to clinically neutral terms (e.g., “expresses intent to seriously harm an identifiable person; reports recent acquisition of a weapon”) and remove unnecessary detail about the method. Keep the ethical dilemma intact without explicit descriptions.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make both options shorter and more parallel, and remove embedded implementation details. For example: 
- Choice 1: “Maintain confidentiality and intensify outpatient management with urgent psychiatry evaluation.” 
- Choice 2: “Breach confidentiality to warn the identifiable person and notify campus security.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the moral/clinical pull so Choice 1 is not obviously unsafe/negligent. As written (named victim + address + knife purchase + imminent return tomorrow + you judge ‘credible risk of serious violence’), most clinicians will feel compelled to warn/protect. To restore equipoise, make the threat less imminent/less specific OR add countervailing harms of disclosure that are concrete and serious. For example: (a) change to ‘intrusive violent images and angry fantasies’ with conditional statements (‘sometimes I think about…’) and no weapon purchase, or uncertainty about the victim’s location; OR (b) keep some specificity but add that disclosure is likely to precipitate immediate self-harm, housing loss, or immigration/academic expulsion that would end care, and that you can arrange same-day psychiatric evaluation with means-restriction (e.g., he agrees to surrender the knife to a third party/lockbox) and continuous monitoring. Also add a realistic risk that police contact could escalate or misidentify him, making disclosure ethically costly rather than straightforward.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious ‘third options’ that would dissolve the binary, especially involuntary emergency evaluation/commitment, mobile crisis response, or contacting a threat-assessment team. Add explicit constraints such as: you are in a state where involuntary hold requires clear imminent intent and he denies intent/plan and does not meet criteria; you cannot legally detain him; mobile crisis cannot arrive before he leaves; no on-call psychiatrist is available; and institutional policy offers only two permissible actions in this situation (maintain confidentiality with urgent follow-up vs targeted warning/disclosure). Alternatively, incorporate the best-available non-disclosure protective steps into Choice 1 (e.g., immediate same-day psychiatric assessment already scheduled) and explicitly state that seeking involuntary hospitalization is not legally available.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, widely taught ‘duty to protect/warn’ standards plus the high-specificity/weapon/imminence details make disclosure feel like the clear standard of care even if the statute is permissive. To avoid a guideline/legal override, revise to a jurisdiction and fact pattern where standards are genuinely discretionary: specify that state law is permissive with no duty-to-warn requirement; professional guidance emphasizes individualized risk assessment and least-intrusive interventions; and the risk does not clearly meet mandatory reporting thresholds (e.g., no stated time, ambivalent intent, agrees to means-restriction and rapid evaluation). Add that you consulted your clinic’s risk-management/covering psychiatrist who confirms both paths are professionally defensible in this gray zone.

feedback.clinical:
distinctness_actionability: Make each option a specific, implementable set of orders and ensure they are mutually exclusive. For example:
- Choice 1: “Do not disclose to third parties today; complete a structured violence risk assessment; create a written safety plan; initiate emergency psychiatric evaluation today (ED/CPEP) on a voluntary basis; schedule psychiatry within 24–48 hours; remove/secure weapon plan; document rationale.”
- Choice 2: “Disclose only the minimum necessary information today to campus police/security and the named potential victim; request a welfare check and weapon intervention; arrange emergency psychiatric evaluation (voluntary or, if criteria met, initiate involuntary hold); document what was disclosed and to whom.”
Also clarify whether the clinician is a psychotherapist with authority to initiate involuntary evaluation/hold; if not, specify referral process.

- Specify whether he has a specific plan beyond having a knife (time/place/means), any prior violence, substance use, psychosis/mania, and access to the partner.
- Clarify whether he meets criteria for emergency involuntary evaluation/hold in your jurisdiction; if he does, mention that it is an available third path but is being considered alongside confidentiality vs warning (or explicitly constrain the binary by stating you can request an emergency evaluation but still must decide about warning/disclosure).
- Clarify what “urgent psychiatric follow-up” means (same day vs next day) because the partner returns tomorrow.
- Consider deleting or tightening less decision-relevant descriptors like “after a breakup” unless it’s needed to establish motive.
- Briefly note current suicidal ideation status only if it affects disposition; otherwise omit.

- Reframe Choice 1 as “maintain confidentiality but initiate emergency psychiatric evaluation today and intensify monitoring,” making it closer to standard practice while still ethically costly due to breach risk.
Also specify the clinician type (psychologist/psychiatrist/therapist) and setting resources (access to crisis team/security).

- Soften certainty: replace “credible risk” with “concerning but not clearly imminent risk,” or “risk assessment suggests elevated risk but imminence is uncertain.”

Specifically: (1) Rephrase 'You judge there is a credible risk of serious violence' to make risk substantial but not near-certain/imminent (e.g., 'risk is concerning but hard to gauge; he has no prior violence and expresses ambivalence'). (2) Add concrete limits/harms of disclosure: campus police response may be punitive (arrest, weapon charges), could escalate retaliation, and may deter him from any future care. data.vignette: A 26-year-old graduate student is in outpatient psychotherapy for severe major depression. Today he reports persistent homicidal ideation toward an identifiable former partner. He names her but gives no time or place. He denies intent to act, denies substance use, and has no history of violence. He reports recently acquiring a weapon and says he could access her when she returns to campus for classes tomorrow. He refuses hospitalization and says any disclosure will end treatment and likely trigger campus discipline and loss of his student visa. You can offer a same-day emergency psychiatric evaluation, but mobile crisis cannot arrive before he leaves, and in your jurisdiction an involuntary hold requires stated imminent intent, which he continues to deny. Clinic leadership confirms that, under state law and policy, either maintaining confidentiality with urgent escalation of care or making a limited protective disclosure is legally permissible here. You must decide before he leaves the office.
data.choice_1: Maintain confidentiality today and arrange same-day emergency psychiatric evaluation.
data.choice_2: Disclose minimum necessary information today to campus security and the identified person.

data.vignette: A 26-year-old graduate student is in outpatient psychotherapy for severe major depression. Today he reports persistent homicidal ideation toward an identifiable former partner. He names her but gives no time or place. He denies intent to act, denies substance use, and has no history of violence. He reports recently acquiring a weapon and says he could access her when she returns to campus for classes tomorrow. He refuses hospitalization and says any disclosure will end treatment and likely trigger campus discipline and loss of his student visa. You can offer a same-day emergency psychiatric evaluation, but mobile crisis cannot arrive before he leaves, and in your jurisdiction an involuntary hold requires stated imminent intent, which he continues to deny. Clinic leadership confirms that, under state law and policy, either maintaining confidentiality with urgent escalation of care or making a limited protective disclosure is legally permissible here. You must decide before he leaves the office.

choice_1.choice: Maintain confidentiality today and arrange same-day emergency psychiatric evaluation.

choice_2.choice: Disclose minimum necessary information today to campus security and the identified person.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add that the patient explicitly refuses any protective disclosure (e.g., 'He explicitly refuses you contacting campus security or the former partner') and that the former partner is unaware/unable to consent to risk mitigation (e.g., 'She has not been informed and cannot take precautions unless contacted').

Add a clause stating that the patient is likely to leave immediately and may not attend the emergency evaluation unless you involve security/third parties (e.g., “he says he will walk out and not go to the ER if you don’t promise confidentiality”).

Add a clause that he refuses to attend the emergency evaluation/ED and will leave the clinic immediately, making it unlikely any clinical intervention will occur before the partner returns to campus tomorrow.

Add one clause making the justice stakes explicit (e.g., “the former partner is also a student with a right to equal protection and campus security has a duty to warn identifiable potential victims”), so nondisclosure can be fairly described as shifting risk/burden onto others and disclosure as promoting equitable protection.

data.vignette: A 26-year-old graduate student is in outpatient psychotherapy for severe major depression. Today he reports persistent homicidal ideation toward an identifiable former partner. He names her but gives no time or place. He denies intent to act, denies substance use, and has no history of violence. He reports recently acquiring a weapon and says he could access her when she returns to campus for classes tomorrow. He explicitly refuses you contacting campus security or the former partner. He says he will leave immediately and will not go for emergency evaluation if confidentiality is not maintained. He refuses hospitalization and says any disclosure will end treatment and likely trigger campus discipline and loss of his student visa. The former partner is also a student and is unaware of the risk, so she cannot take precautions unless informed. You can offer a same-day emergency psychiatric evaluation, but mobile crisis cannot arrive before he leaves, and in your jurisdiction an involuntary hold requires stated imminent intent, which he continues to deny. Clinic leadership confirms that either urgent escalation of care with confidentiality or a limited protective disclosure is legally permissible. You must decide before he leaves the office.

choice_1.choice: Maintain confidentiality today and arrange same-day emergency psychiatric evaluation.

choice_2.choice: Disclose minimum necessary information today to campus security and the identified person.

data.vignette: A 26-year-old graduate student is in outpatient psychotherapy for severe major depression. Today he reports persistent homicidal ideation toward an identifiable former partner. He names her but gives no time or place. He denies intent to act, denies substance use, and has no history of violence. He reports recently acquiring a weapon and says he could access her when she returns to campus for classes tomorrow. He explicitly refuses you contacting campus security or the former partner. He says he will leave immediately and will not go for emergency evaluation if confidentiality is not maintained. He refuses hospitalization and says any disclosure will end treatment and likely trigger campus discipline and loss of his student visa. The former partner is also a student and is unaware of the risk, so she cannot take precautions unless informed. You can offer a same-day emergency psychiatric evaluation, but mobile crisis cannot arrive before he leaves, and in your jurisdiction an involuntary hold requires stated imminent intent, which he continues to deny. Clinic leadership confirms that either urgent escalation of care with confidentiality or a limited protective disclosure is legally permissible. You must decide before he leaves the office.

choice_1.choice: Maintain confidentiality today and arrange same-day emergency psychiatric evaluation.

choice_2.choice: Disclose minimum necessary information today to campus security and the identified person.
